awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Climate controls on carbon accumulation in upland permafrost at millennial scales
awd_abstract_narration:
Permafrost, or perennially frozen ground, holds a large reservoir of carbon. The overarching goal of this study is to look to the recent geologic past to improve understanding of how future changes in climate may impact carbon accumulation and release. The investigators have combined expertise in paleoecology, paleoclimatology, surficial geology, geochronology, and quantitiative geomorphology. Together, they will quantify the relationship between climate and the mass of carbon that accumulated under distinctly different climates of the past 40,000 years in hilly upland regions of the Arctic, which will complment previous work on the effects of climate change on permafrost carbon in lakes and peatlands of low-lying terrain. Results will add paleo perspectives to the Permafrost Carbon Network, part of the Study of Environmental Arctic Change. The project will provide training for graduate and undergraduate students, and the team of investigators includes an early career scientist.

In this study, the investigators will combine field-collections, analysis of sediment cores, and modeling to quantify the millennial scale relationship between climate and permafrost carbon accumulation at an upland study site in the Eight Mile Lake watershed in the northern foothills of the Alaska Range. They will take multiple sediment cores along hillslope transects to map the underlying stratigraphic framework; contrast the surficial materials mantling both a short and a long slope to infer the relative roles of slope-length- versus slope-angle-dependent transport processes; and use these data in a numerical model to simulate hillslope evolution and assess downslope geomorphic processes that transfer sediment and sequester carbon. The investigators will also use radiocarbon dating of macrofossils to determine the extent to which organic matter has been stratigraphically mixed and to distninguish millennial-scale periods of accumulation; evaluate pollen and macrofossiles for community characteristics and grain size distributions; and analyze sediment sequences for a suite of bio-physical properties to quantify carbon mass, accumulation, and decomposition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Climate controls on carbon accumulation in upland permafrost at millennial scales

 

Irina Overeem, CU Boulder

 

Organic-rich soils of the Arctic store frozen carbon. Climate warming thaws the permafrost and controls the exchange of carbon between this reservoir and the atmosphere. How climate and permafrost carbon interact on the long-term is still uncertain. This project focused on climate changes during the recent geologic past, over 1000’s of years. The project aimed to quantify how much and where carbon accumulated under distinctly different climate states.

Our team built permafrost and landscape modeling tools to assist the project field campaign and inform site selections in the watershed of Eight Mile Lake, interior Alaska. This included detailed terrain analysis of the high-resolution ARCTIC Digital Elevation Model data. We assessed topographical factors, like slope, aspect and curvature, important to carbon accumulation and subsequent reworking by hillslope and stream processes. This data analysis supported the site selections of subsurface cores which showed that carbon accumulation in interior Alaska occurs more rapidly with decreased temperature and high moisture regimes. Notably, fast carbon accumulation happened in terrain depressions (Marshall et al, 2023).

We advanced development and coupled models from the permafrost modeling system (Overeem et al., 2018) and Landlab (Tucker et al., 2022).  These models can all be ‘classified’ as reduced-complexity models, meaning they use simplified thermal processes and empirical geomorphic transport processes to allow the testing of hypotheses over longterm climate changes. We deemed the use of simple models necessary for the longterm timescale this project addresses, both from a computational perspective as well as from a theoretical understanding and input scarcity perspective.

We combined a permafrost model (Kudryavtsev model) and landscape process models (hillslope diffusion, streampower SPACE model, Overland Flow model) for Eight Mile Lake.  To make these permafrost and landscape process models more widely applicable we leveraged “data components’ development. Data components are part of cyber-infrastructure framework development ongoing in the Community Surface Dynamics Modeling System (CSDMS). Data components aim to make data preparation tasks more user-friendly and more easily integrated in a modeling workflow. Specifically for permafrost landscapes, we pushed for development of data components that allow ingesting topographic data, climate data through mining of global weather synthesis data (ERA5), and soil property data (through Soil Grids). To highlight how this model workflow is implemented for other users, we constructed a case-study, that is published in Geoscientific Model Development (Gan et al., 2024). These models and components are documented, available as open-source code, and undergo continuous integration and maintenance through the CSDMS cyberinfrastructure.

The project helped fund a research semester and summer research for a graduate student and funded work on a case-study for a postdoctoral fellow. This was professional development with an emphasis on cyberinfrastructure skills for these early-career scientists, but in addition it provided a broadening of their key research areas (glaciology and hydrology respectively).

The findings of this project have sparked a new Machine-Learning modeling effort as part of a MURI project W911NF-22-S-0007, Synoptic measurement of stream and atmospheric indicators to improve the monitoring and prediction of climate-induced permafrost degradation across Alaska. The machine-learning analysis uses an expert database of abrupt thaw features in the permafrost landscape and investigates what are controls on these features, including detailed terrain controls, and simple modeled permafrost parameters.

 


Last Modified: 03/10/2025
Modified by: Irina Overeem
